column1: ULTRACONFIDENTIEL DESIGN, Amazon Blink - Fashion Studio, Gurgaon, India;"ULTRACONFIDENTIEL DESIGN";"Amazon Blink - Fashion Studio";"Gurgaon
column4: 000 Sft. Ultraconfidentiel Design has designed the fashion studio for Amazon BLINK
column6: India. This was a very unique project earlier harbouring New York and London
column7: Amazon gave us the opportunity to conceptualize the first of its kind Amazon Fashion Studio in India. Designed to boost creativity and interactions between all generations of fashion designers
column8: BLINK studio’s energy is fully enhanced thought open spaces and collaborative areas. The subtle blend of modern designs and revisited Indian traditions inhabits this studio and gives its uniqueness. All along the place
column9: details have been thought by Ultraconfidentiel’s Design team to tell a story and depict not only fashion but also the essence of India. For this studio
column10: one of the requirements was to bring some Indian touches though the space to create its identity for instance
column11: we decided to focus on phone booths to show the cultural diversity of India though fabrics specific to different regions. The use of modern version of Mughal Jaalis specially invented and customized for this project
column12: and faded-red color micro-concrete flooring to remind the sandstone used in architecture through the Indian sub-continent. The design expectations were set high. It was a challenging project given by its nature and also the fact that it was our first assignment for a Fashion Studio. A lot of technical aspects were involved which made the project more enticing. This Studio spans across 44
column14: Gurgaon and has over 14 on-Body bays
column18: a large office space and operations area. The premise can also un-fold itself for large gathering and corporate meets. The rustic and industrial look with subtle glimpse of Indian fashion
column19: textile and elements completes the individuality of fashion and creates its own unique style.";;;;;;"Kapill Kamra";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/I3ZeZyjvCeDOT5no.jpg

column1: WY-TO ARCHITECTS, Merdeka Textile Museum , Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia;"WY-TO ARCHITECTS";"Merdeka Textile Museum";"Kuala Lumpur
column3: 101.68044212814";;Office;;;2024;"The overarching ambition for the new Merdeka Textile Museum is to become an inclusive cultural institution for Everyone
column4: from Novice to Expert. Guiding the design articulation is the focus on the look and feel which will communicate a coherent visitor journey through the 8 collection themes. 6 distinctive design elements were identified and explored to provide tangibility in “Look” and “Feel”. They assisted in strengthening the framework led by “Bunga Pecah Lapan” (a motif found in traditional Malay textiles) and “Drape
column6: Fold”. The juxtaposition of these elements proposes a sense of grandeur and dynamism that is subtle yet impactful
column8: they exuberate a universal language by involving the engagement of the 5 human senses
column9: fitting for the inclusive museum journey through the long-standing heritage of Malayan textiles.";;;;;;"WY-TO Group";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/M8H60sFEG6b4ZwPC.jpg

column1: WY-TO ARCHITECTS, St James Power Station Heritage Trail And Gallery , Singapore, Singapore;"WY-TO ARCHITECTS";"St James Power Station Heritage Trail And Gallery";"Singapore
column4: a glorious industrial power house of Singapore is now a notable heritage icon in Singapore and a successful example of adaptive reuse. It is important to pay homage to the historical architecture while integrating the heritage trail and gallery with a renewed landscape and interior of the Dyson office. The design direction of the gallery aims to showcase the value of heritage through the legacy of its materials and artefacts. Moving towards the future
column5: it is pivotal to give the heritage a new lustre and patina. The use of corten steel for the outdoor interpretive panels is reminiscent of the distinctive red brick façade. New materials such as steel beams and granites are the site’s material palette. The interior design of the upper-level floor slabs in the Dyson office made use of layered wood and white painted finishes
column6: which inspired the principle of cohesively layering and overlapping various materials in the indoor gallery. The L-wall of the gallery features a niche wall with various elements which curate visitor journeys into one that has layers of discovery and exploration. The design intent is to craft a coherent visitor journey of discovery with clear navigation by connecting various themes through a simple and timeless spatial approach. Our evidence-based approach to design defines the design language to allow the new elements to merge with existing fabric
column7: ensuring that the historical artefacts take precedence throughout the heritage trail.";;;;;;"Mapletree Investments";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/F4fg0E67hsioq6ur.jpg
column9: http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/R0XyjaoS6nG20dTZ.jpg"

column1: WY-TO ARCHITECTS, Good Design Research Pop-up Exhibition , Singapore, Singapore;"WY-TO ARCHITECTS";"Good Design Research Pop-up Exhibition";"Singapore
column3: 103.81996590381";;"Cultural space";;;2022;"The Good Design Research Pop-up Exhibition is conceptualized to bring design closer to the everyday man. Translated through the design of 3 mega coves
column4: the curatorial theme “A Day in The Life” synergizes to house a curated set of prototypes and research. The exhibition design colour scheme – Green
column7: shape the visitor’s journey through daily ticks of the clock: Morning
column9: and Night. The curved niches were further developed to translate designs empowering nature in impacting our day-to-day activities. Sustainably constructed in standard-sized plywood and recycled steel structures
column10: these free-standing inward panels were strategically placed. They assisted in dynamically opening up multiple vistas for content glimpses of exploration in the open space while doubling up to create focused display views for the permanent shops behind. Overhangs were the final design touch in ensuring the temporary outdoor exhibition remains immersive next to the busy road. They function to diffuse traffic noise at peak hours of the day while communicating through form design’s impact in resolving challenges.";;;;;;"WY-TO Group";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/2rkWdcL4AsYPRRmC.jpg

column1: WY-TO ARCHITECTS, Gallery Children's Biennale 2023: Let's Make A Better Place , Singapore, Singapore;"WY-TO ARCHITECTS";"Gallery Children's Biennale 2023: Let's Make A Better Place";"Singapore
column3: 103.819911";;"Cultural space";;;2023;"The Gallery Children’s Biennale has been a key programme of National Gallery Singapore since 2017
column4: embodying the Gallery’s commitment to inspiring young
column5: curious minds with art. It aims to explore the many ways that children can learn and play while also engaging more with the world around them. This year
column6: the Biennale features 11 interactive and immersive artworks responding to the theme of “Let’s Make A Better Place
column7: ” inviting children and adults to discover how we can create a world built upon this year’s core values of care
column9: imagination and collaboration. Ten artists from Singapore and beyond conceived new artworks for the Biennale. These artists are: Arahmaiani (Indonesia)
column13: LittleCr3atures® x Jevon Chandra x Lynette Quek (Singapore)
column18: and Ly Yeow (Singapore). Centred on art created for
column19: with
column20: and by children
column21: the Biennale is a warm and welcoming space for everyone to have conversations about their dreams
column23: and even struggles. This edition also includes both digital and on-site programmes that will inspire visitors of all ages.";;;;;;"National Gallery Singapore";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/5nGcWW19EwBMs4t8.jpg

column1: WY-TO ARCHITECTS, Gallery Children's Biennale 2021: Why Art Matters , Singapore, Singapore;"WY-TO ARCHITECTS";"Gallery Children's Biennale 2021: Why Art Matters";"Singapore
column3: 103.819836";;"Cultural space";;;2022;"The Gallery Children’s Biennale is a space for self-expression and creative exploration
column4: empowering children with a renewed sense of empathy and confidence to engage with the ever-changing world around them while embracing the shared values of acceptance
column6: nine artists from Singapore and Southeast Asia were asked to address the theme
column7: “Why Art Matters”. Faced with the emergence of the Covid-19 pandemic
column8: the gallery had to re-think the notion of engagement. In response
column9: the artists were invited to conceive artworks as both online and on-site interactive works and physical installations. With a range of programmes for children and families
column10: the Gallery Children’s Biennale aim to inspire young minds with artistic experiences that can transform a child’s understanding of the world around them

column4: 73.703040363676";;"Cultural space";;;2023;"Our design creates a world-class cultural destination
column5: that celebrates the rich history and evolution of India while accenting the importance of the Gujarat region in that story. The museum complex will be an enriching experience that will delight
column7: instilling a sense of pride for generations to come. The Museum Complex is located on a commanding site overlooking the Narmada River. The river is central to a developing tourist district whose focus is the Statue of Unity
column8: the largest statue in the world and a significant landmark for visitors. The new complex acts as a cultural gateway for the pilgrimage to the statue. It is visible from the Ekta entry to the district
column9: from across the river

column1: ULTRACONFIDENTIEL DESIGN, Mankind Pharma Limited, A Class Apart, Okhla Phase III, Okhla Industrial Estate, New Delhi, Delhi 110020, Inde;"ULTRACONFIDENTIEL DESIGN";"Mankind Pharma Limited
column7: 77.267152761995";;Office;;;2022;"Mankind Pharma is one of India’s leading and fast-growing pharmaceutical companies. Their new Head Office at New Delhi is situated right in the heart of Okhla Phase III which is the hub of industrial and commercial activity. Spread over seven floors the new company headquarters has been designed as a state-of-the-art corporate office space. Ultraconfidentiel Design was commissioned to develop 125 000 Sq. Ft. of office space for the company’s employees across various hierarchies. The idea was to seamlessly carve-out spaces for the various brand divisions of the company
column9: collaborative working and spaces to relax and rejuvenate. The office draws inspiration from the progressive nature of the company and develops a clean and healthy workspace that favours growth and productivity based on its ethos. The consequent design is a sublime space wrapped in a white canvas
column10: carved-out from large volumes and voids while maximizing the use of natural light. The dynamic office design propels the company’s work culture into a modern territory of future-proof workspaces. The site finds itself amidst a lush green neighbourhood. The built form allows for a great view as well as an ample amount of natural light
column11: the effect of which is maximized by the expansive use of white marble. The marble-clad walls of the triple-height atrium at the front entrance instil a sense of tranquillity and act as a buffer between the outside and inside. Juxtaposed to the white canvas is a hand-beaten brass reception table that forms the foreground of an open courtyard laden with trees and shrubs. A well-designed space has the capacity to affect human behaviour. The open-plan workspaces are strategically placed in order to maximize productivity and longevity of the workspace without compromising the privacy of the work profile. Utmost care has been taken to keep the functional and technical aspects as the primary driving factors for the design. The design promotes the concepts of teamwork and collaboration
column12: thus intermittent spaces for collaborative working and relaxation can be found throughout the various floors of the office. A carefully chosen palette of materials on one hand infuses an element of luxury and on the other ensures high performance and longevity of the workspace. The use of brass accents was a crucial design decision and as a result
column13: the metal can be seen taking the form of a suspended mobile in the triple-height waiting lounge
column14: as do the customised light fixtures and the see-through partition screens across the office space. The office space makes use of smart technology to facilitate smooth operations across the extensive built-up area. Interactive digital screens in the guest area assist users with information about the company. Solutions like access-controlled cabins
column15: sensor-based lighting and wireless chargers integrated within the workstations make for a future-ready modern workspace. Workspaces of tomorrow need to be flexible and adaptive to the rapidly changing trends of the corporate ecosystem. The new Mankind Head Office excels in doing so with its adaptive
column16: mobility-oriented and high-performance workspaces that can be reconfigured to the needs of a growing company and transform themselves to host a variety of uses in years to come.";;;;;;"Kapill Kamra";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/2BWifKbUAFmEUNjj.jpg

column1: STUDIO GGSV, From Paris With Love - Galeries Lafayette Shenzen , Shenzen, Chine;"STUDIO GGSV";"From Paris With Love - Galeries Lafayette Shenzen";"Shenzen
column3: 114.06484996278";;Retail;;;2023;"An immersive experience between dream and reality: Studio GGSV takes over the windows and store of Galeries Lafayette in Shenzhen . After GL Haussmann
column4: GL Shenzhen in turn invite Studio GGSV to imagine the windows of this department store and offer the public an escape to a dream world. For this occasion
column5: Gaëlle Gabillet and Stéphane Villard have seized on the bucolic and aesthetic codes of the Art Nouveau heritage as well as the symbolism of literati stones. These traditional Chinese stones representing natural elements inspired the duo of artists fascinated by mineral materials. From these inspirations result suspended landscape installations bordering on surrealism like rocks of scholars having left their support to float and create a city in the air. Using digital manipulations
column6: the GGSV studio imagined various digital floral and mineral sculptures in full fulfillment giving the illusion of coming to life before our eyes. They have thus succeeded in transporting us into an augmented dreamlike universe. Elements of the GL heritage such as the dome of the Galeries Haussmann also come to bud on these futuristic decorations. These created from scratch eventually transformed the store into a fantastic immersive garden. Visitors are therefore invited to navigate in this universe on the border between history and virtuality
column7: from Paris to Shenzhen. This installation is a visual experience
column8: where the harmony between past and technology is revealed. A poetic response and a work of audacious composition characteristic of the GGSV studio which pays homage by reinterpreting the GL heritage between Art Nouveau and Digital Art. This artistic encounter playing with cultural borders offers the public a unique immersive experience that unites Paris and Shenzhen. The Shenzhen GLs thus become an artistic theater
column9: where creativity blends with cultural heritage. Design of 8 showcases
column10: 2 videos and 4 corners / opening at the end of July 2023";;;;;;"1 et 2 : Studio GGSV

column6: equivalent to that of the largest lake in Japan
column7: Biwako. They revealed the relationship between the depth of the bedrock
column8: its composition and the amount of water flowing through it. As early as the Heian era (794-1192)
column9: people knew about the abundance of groundwater
column10: but could not explain its origin or course. The book Water calling tells the story of the evolution of the relationship between water and human beings
column11: from the formation of the water table 5 million years ago
column13: the emergence of a mythology to the deployment of urban space and its networks

column16: a sound of water. A double-sided printed cover reveals a story of water in Kyoto through the translucence of the paper. column4: featuring a series of customised Art & Design elements by Isabelle Miaja and carefully selected partners from all over the world. The project brief was to explore one of the major issues today the connection – and disconnection with other human beings as a result of the technology driven world we live in. Sociologists are raising concerned questions about the fact that people spend less time together physically and warning that technology is creating a parallel world distancing us from our humanity. Taking on the theme of “Social FlexAbility” MIAJA Design Group was challenged to design a flexible and engaging space where guests can activate the social experience of their choice.";;;;;;"Mark Luscombe-Whyte";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/bubbRJt70407wFob.jpg

column1: AURELIEN CHEN, Dragon Mountain Tourist Center, Zhulongshan, Rizhao, Shandong, China;"AURELIEN CHEN";"Dragon Mountain Tourist Center";"Zhulongshan
column6: a fragmented architectural complex. An architectural complex adapting to its natural surroundings The entrance to Dragon Mountain natural tourist site is marked by a view of the mountain within the axis of the site’s entrance alley. This alley splits into two separate lanes once entered site: one lane climbs up towards the mountain and the other descends slightly towards two small ponds
column7: situated on a lower level and surrounded by trees. Aiming to adapt the complex to this natural site
column8: the main architectural stance was to fragment the 3000 m² surface into five architectural elements adapting to the topography and the natural context of the site. The five architectural elements are situated and organized around a small square. The design of these buildings is pure and slender. They are low on the side facing the site entrance and they rise up and grow in height towards their mountain side. On their lower side
column9: with their mass
column10: these buildings are connected to the Earth. On their higher side
column15: the human being is closely connected to the Sky and the Earth
column16: and according to Taoism it is part of a Cosmic Triad with Heaven and Earth. There is a dialogue between the curved buildings and a tension between volumes and empty spaces. In these empty spaces
column17: landscape perspectives are created in order to frame the mountain. Entrance Gate In China
column18: entrances to modern touristic sites usually follow a standard approaching sequence: a public square with a monumental sculpture at its centre followed by an entrance gate reminiscent of the traditional ones
column19: a ticket counter and
column20: lastly
column21: an information and welcome centre. Here
column22: the entrance gate to the site is incorporated into the architectural composition. It houses the ticket counter on one side and the security staff area on the other. Its mass is both architecture and sculpture. It is a visual landmark and attracts the visitors in the distance. The gate is composed by three rows of arched walls that
column23: in a way common to urban public spaces
column24: creates and delimits the public square just outside the site. Walls are rooted in the ground and they reach for the sky in their centre
column25: reminding of the mountain peaks and also the verticality of the Cosmic Triad Earth- Human Being – Heaven. There is no portal. Instead
column27: a void becoming a landscape frame on the mountain peaks far in the distance. The consecutive walls remind of the fortifications that once surrounded cities and traditional palaces and create a peculiar sequence of approach: in their intervals
column28: the visitor discovers the entrances to each separate building. Materials Stone cladding expresses the concept of mass connected to the Earth and allows a delicate integration of the gate with its natural surroundings and with local architecture. Raw concrete made from wood formwork reminds of the irregularity of natural elements and can be easily built even by unskilled workers. A natural screen made of natural bamboo sticks creates a subtle layer between massive concrete/stone and transparent glass. Credits Architects: Aurelien Chen / Urban and rural planning and design institute of CSCEC Partners in charge: Aurelien Chen

column5: 2024";"Cultural space";;;2023;"A table is an invitation to dwell together
column6: in the same space and around the same table. It is an encouragement to enter into a dialogue
column7: to convene and to think about how we could reinstate and re-establish our relationship to nature and the Earth. In today’s changing times

column9: around which we will sit together in a modest
column10: low structure and in an atmosphere reminiscent of Toguna huts of the Dogon people in Mali
column12: designed to bring all members of a community together in discussion. Here we can eat
column18: and decide. Built with bio-sourced and low-carbon materials
column19: the structure appears like a skeleton. Sustainably sourced timber ribs are arranged to support a suspended pleated roof. Echoing the structures of tree leaves
column20: the Pavilion embraces the nature of the park in which it emerges. Reminding us of the many lives blossoming beneath our feet
column21: the concave lines of its perimeter are drawn from the forms in the stems and canopies of adjacent trees. While rooted in its place and welcoming the space of the park with its open gallery-like envelope

column6: Scotland announces the launch of two new Grand Suites set to join the rake in May 2024. Mirroring the look and feel of a luxury country house

column9: Twin and Single cabins. SUBLIME BY DESIGN: A REFLECTION OF SCOTLAND’S EPHEMERAL LANDSCAPE The spacious Grand Suites brim with elegant references to Scottish culture and its outstanding natural beauty. Interiors take inspiration from the destination through the hues of green
column11: beige and blue used for the handcrafted wall-covering
column13: which reflect the tones of the surrounding landscape. Local materials like stone and wood are abundantly used in the lavish ensuite bathrooms
column14: while decorative patterns echo Edwardian flair
column15: Pictish stones motifs and Celtic symbolism
column16: all artfully designed by Tristan Auer. Enveloping dark wooden wall panelling embellished with intricate marquetry form the backdrop for a double bed with embossed bedhead
column19: and places to relax on a sumptuous sofa and armchair. Guests of the Grand Suites will also benefit from private transfers and a rejuvenating treatment in the train’s moving spa - the only one of its kind in Europe. AN ELEVATED EXPERIENCE OF SCOTLAND IN MOTION The Royal Scotsman offers an all-encompassing experience of the Highlands with its two-to seven-night selection of themed journeys
column20: all leaving and returning to Edinburgh Waverley station. Guests are invited to embrace the sophisticated camaraderie spirit

column7: the United Nations House brings together on a single site and within an iconic building the 34 agencies
column8: funds and programmes of the United Nations System already present in Senegal
column9: some of which are regional or sub-regional representations covering several countries. The aim of this ambitious project is to provide the United Nations system with a tool for working in a cohesive and coherent manner to improve collaboration in support of the people of Senegal and West Africa
column10: within a secure framework that complies with all the requirements laid down by the United Nations. The challenge of this emblematic building is to illustrate the unity of the agencies
column11: but also their independence and their influence on a national and regional scale. Eco-responsible and sustainable
column12: the project is reminiscent of a water wheel
column13: symbolising the influence of the institution across the region and the convergence of expertise. This large white circular volume unfurls seven wings of equal size
column14: opening out onto the city and organising a new central space on a controlled scale. This centre is designed as a unifying void that accommodates the official functions as well as a vast public agora. Around the perimeter
column15: the office floors are curved and open
column16: preserving the independence of the agencies while encouraging synergy between them. The spatial organisation of the programme echoes the form: the official spaces are located right at the heart of the building: the amphitheatre and reception areas will host international conferences
column17: seminars and debates. This central activity will be supported by a ring of public and shared spaces such as IT support

column20: catering areas
column21: etc. Connected to the shared circle

column24: take their place in the spokes

column1: JAKOB+MACFARLANE, New Campus Of The French University Of Egypt, Cairo, Université Française d’Egypte, 21 Ismailia Desert Road Ville Shorouk, Le Caire, Egypte;JAKOB+MACFARLANE;"New Campus Of The French University Of Egypt
column8: the French University of Egypt (UFE) is located in El Shorouk
column9: a city in the Greater Cairo area that is home to numerous schools and universities. Its current premises were insufficiently adapted for a growing population of students
column10: therefore the UFE and the Agence Française de Développement have put in place a programme for developing a new 24.500 m2 campus aiming to accommodate 3000 students by 2025
column11: and 7000 in the 2nd phase. Among the project's key objectives was the creation of a campus that would be exemplary in terms of environmental innovation and serve as a cultural showcase of Franco-Egyptian partnership. The future campus of the UFE is imagined first and foremost as an oasis - a haven for learning
column12: a place of cooling shade protected by a sun-shading roof. Recessed gardens arranged between the buildings will use plants that can thrive in extremely dry environments their irrigation will be enabled by the grey water treatment system. A grid-shaped pergola roof in aluminium and steel will create shadow for buildings and circulation spaces. It will also incorporate an array of solar panels to cover on-site energy needs. The Auditorium
column14: as well as recreation spaces and cafeterias will frame the central square. The Auditorium will stand out for its brickwork envelope shaped into an organic form. Architecturally and functionally
column15: our intention is to create a campus open to the city
column16: a project that will serve as an ambassador of the two cultures. We imagine an inspiring
column17: friendly and efficient environment for the faculty and students
column18: but also an integrated part of the neighbourhood
column19: a place that will hold value for the surrounding community. A number of the campus facilities will be made available for public use. The project will use locally sourced building materials such as the clay bricks
column20: the principal material for the facades. Earthen construction will also be used. Digital technologies will act as a bridge between traditional techniques and contemporary architectural solutions. The topography of gardens recessed into the ground will facilitate water retention. These gardens will form a series of amphitheatre-shaped spaces with a pleasant microclimate - an outdoor extension of the classrooms

column1: VIEWPORT STUDIO, Virgin Galactic Spaceport, New Mexico, Co Rd A021, Truth or Consequences, NM 87901, United States;"VIEWPORT STUDIO";"Virgin Galactic Spaceport
column7: 2024";Hotel;;;2022;"What is the starting point for something that has never been designed before? Virgin Galactic – the company launching commercial space flights for tourists – selected us to curate a combined customer and employee experience alongside a completely bespoke interior design for the public-facing spaces and the operations centre of Spaceport America in the New Mexico desert. Our history of delivering award winning design for the Virgin Group stretches back nearly two decades which has given us an in-depth understanding of their brand DNA. Our starting point was the location of the spaceport and its surrounding landscape. Our team stood on the runway at Spaceport America and stared out to the New Mexico desert which is a stark and beautiful place
column8: rich in colour and texture. This inspiration became the main influence for the design work that followed.";;;;;;"Virgin Galactic";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/VIEWPORT%20STUDIO_VIRGIN%20GALACTIC%20SPACEPORT%2C%20NEW%20MEXICO%20%C2%A9%20VIRGIN%20GALACTIC%20%281%29.jpg

column6: an old building with lime and stone walls once housed a rustic farmhouse. The new owners discovered it in a state of disrepair and entrusted Atelier du Pont with the task of transforming it into their ideal vacation home. The french studio brings all of its aesthetics and know how to the table. Welcome to a typical Mediterranean setting. White lime is omnipresent throughout. It reflects the light and brightens the high interior rooms
column7: which are not a lot open to the outside. Without touching the main structure
column8: the architectural language of the house is redefined and enhanced
column9: combining traditional influences with contemporary accents. Color was used to restructure and delineate these large spaces. A palette of warm
column10: contrasting hues meets white walls and ceilings. This creative project boldly twists local architectural codes into a new chromatic universe. It showcases Menorcan craftsmanship and adds character and authenticity to the house. Most of the furniture is masonry
column11: blending seamlessly with the architecture. Natural mineral materials are used
column12: such as earthen concrete and earthenware. A little further down the grounds
column13: a swimming pool protected by typical sandstone walls forms a little corner of paradise. A sense of calm and serenity reigns here. column1: RDAI, Maison Hermès Madison, New York, 706 Madison Avenue, NY 10065 New York;RDAI;"Maison Hermès Madison
column5: 2024";Retail;;;2022;"The Hermès Madison Avenue flagship store is a union of New York dynamism and Parisian elegance
column6: and an ambitious fusion of three existing buildings. The historical 706 Madison Bank building plan offers a deep perspective
column8: rhythmed with a sequence of small rooms. In contrast
column9: 704 Madison - a combination of two town houses - features voluptuous curves and smooth lines a more organic architecture in tone and form
column10: with multiple and inverted arches. We worked to reinforce this contrast and complementarity of atmosphere which runs throughout 706 and 704 enabling their histories to communicate with each other and allowing the public to discover their identities. The interiors explore
column11: without any nostalgia and with a resolutely modern approach
column12: an expression of what “Art deco” could be today
column13: taking subtle cues from the New York Art Deco influence of the early Manhattan Rockefeller and Chrysler skyscrapers with a strong echo to Paris Art Deco periods. The interiors develop in a harmonious style
column15: strong geometry and an extensive range of materials and colors such as green straw marquetry wall panels in the men’s department and equestrian
column16: realized with French decorative artist by Lison de Caunes
column17: gold crackled lacquer wall finish in the perfume department alcoves and celadon green crackled lacquer wall finish in the leather salon both realized by Atelier Maury
column18: the bespoke oyster mushroom fabric covering the jewelry department and private jewelry salon wall walls
column19: which were developed with Grethe Sorensen
column20: Danish textile designer and recycled leather finish wall panels in the men’s VIP salon. The color palettes intensify from floor to floor with tones of green
column21: dark chocolate and cognac on the Bank building side and warm neutrals – ivories
column23: light browns – ochre and dusty pinks at 704 Madison. Decorative details were emphasized and translated into contemporary details such as the “trompe l’oeil” effect of the marble mosaic floor
column25: and the grills of the original bank building’s safe. The Hermès atmosphere was strengthened with references to details from the original Hermes Faubourg
column27: including the leather glass showcases
column29: or the Faubourg mosaic floor pattern. The staircase geometry provides an easy
column30: fluid “promenade” from floor to floor. Organic
column31: curved shapes were expressed in solid and perennial materials
column32: resulting in a high-tech monolithic block stone staircase
column33: with a sense of movement and lightness! The stone stair flights are built with a post tensioning technique
column34: and the guardrails are double beam stone balustrades. A stair that floats upwards. The roof of the 704 building was re-built (providing a double height volume on the fourth floor)
column35: with a domelike double curved glass skylight
column37: which overlooks a lush roof garden designed in collaboration with Miranda Brooks. Once again
column40: and fine details through an expansive glass-fiber bas-relief drawn by the French artist Francois Houtin with the representation of a dense nature turning around the room. The fourth floor welcomes the visitors with a bar
column41: a speak easy and a promenade in the garden. This is a new era of retail where the client is invited to experience the lifestyle of the Maison Hermès.";;;;;;"Kevin Scott";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/RDAI_MAISON%20HERM%C3%88S%20MADISON%2C%20NEW%20YORK%20%C2%A9%20KEVIN%20SCOTT%20%281%29.jpg

column1: WY-TO, Head/home, Singapore, Singapore, Singapore;WY-TO;"Head/home
column5: 2024";"Cultural space";;;2022;"Husband-and-wife artist duo Alfredo and Isabel Aquilizan create works through the process of collecting and collaborating
column6: using materials such as cardboard boxes and personal artefacts to illustrate the ideas of home
column9: and memory. As part of the Gallery Children’s Biennale 2021
column10: the artists have created an immersive
column11: large-scale phygital installation titled Head/Home. On-site
column12: a collaborative workshop was conducted to involve children in the creation of small houses that contribute to the final installation
column13: introducing the ideas of thinking and working with their hands. An online counterpart to the exhibit encourages children to continue the process of creating in their own homes. Children are invited to craft their own cardboard houses and submit them online to be featured in an ever-growing virtual floating city. These homes can also double up as wearable masks! In the Gallery of Self-Portraits
column14: children may take a selfie with their creations and share their stories while discovering those of others. Through familiar landmarks and interactive workshops
column15: the installation encourages children to be imaginative and express what their idea of home is.";;;;;;"Yu Heng";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/WY-TO_HEAD%20HOME%2C%20SINGAPORE%20%C2%A9%20YU%20HENG%20%281%29.jpg

column8: tectonic structure. We studied the perception of the surrounding mountains

The hotel accommodation and facilities are grouped together in the central 6-storey core structure which forms an elevated platform with two chalet-inspired residential buildings above. This platform provides panoramic views of the mountains from the bar
column10: the outdoor swimming pool and lounge areas fitted out with log fires and a film projection station. The architecture and interiors of this alpine retreat have been designed to incite relaxation and revive the senses through an enveloping and cocooning experience in which the mountain views are given primary place. The project is based on the concept of dark to light
column11: of gradually revealing what is hidden as a sensory architectural experience inspired by the surrounding environment. Like a rock emerging from the mountainside
column13: reaching up towards the light. This concept has been applied to the journey that every guest embarks on from the moment they arrive at the underground entrance modelled on a mineral grotto. The building does not impose itself on the landscape but provides a framing of the environment through a play of perspectives and openings on to the exteriors. The interiors are based on a refined elegance using natural materials such as leather
column14: wood and stone that reflect and dialogue with the surrounding nature. Six Senses Crans-Montana is a project balancing a strong aesthetic presence
column15: respect for the environment and architecture that truly belongs in its site where the ‘ski-in and ski-out’ experience complements the extensive wellness spa. For the suites
column16: we wanted to create a sense of ‘coming in from the cold’. The idea that the space is a cabin in the woods
column17: a space to feel warm and safe
column18: while in direct contact with surrounding nature. The rooms are thus lined in rough timber planks and stone-coloured wall render. The windows run the full width
column19: with vast private balconies
column20: taking in the views onto the ski slopes
column21: forest and valley. The natural colour tones of the room were chosen to reinforce the idea of nature. The timber walls open with sliding panels into the bathroom space
column22: which – as if carved into the mountain- is lined in stone. The suites we have designed expresses our idea of luxury at AW². It is understated
column23: with every detail thought-out to create a connection to the context and environment. At the Six Senses Crans-Montana we were able to do so fully
column25: the furniture
column26: the lights and even some of the accessories. Six senses Crans-Montana’s indoor pool was thought-out as a mountain cave pool
column27: while the details and materials are the same as the rest of the project. The stone lined walls and floors are juxtaposed to the sculptured ceiling in wood. The reflection of the timber ceiling battens – 15
column28: 000 of them – in the water creates a play of light with the sunlight filtering through the exterior courtyard lined in birch trees. This is a space that is suspended in time
column29: where the seasons become part of the experience with the white snows in winter and the green leaves of the trees in summer. The spa is a major part of the project with over 2
column30: 000 square metres of space at the heart of the building. The treatment rooms
column31: which we imagined as mountain cabins in the woods
column32: are organised around the Alpine Garden
column33: putting them in direct contact with nature outside. These timber-lined rooms contrast with the green of the trees outside. The wet treatment area offers a unique moment in multi sensorial experiences
column34: all within the curved walled space. As if excavated directly into the mountain face.";;;;;;"Mikael Bénard

column1: CHARLES ZANA, La Résidence, New York, New-York;"CHARLES ZANA";"La Résidence
column4: 2024";"Private residence";;;2022;"A residence for culinary creation Charles Zana signed the opening of La Résidence in New York
column5: the first physical outpost where Yann Nury's cuisine can be enjoyed in a private immersive environment. The project brings together these two enthusiasts to create a personal space of experimentation and conviviality. The loft
column6: located in Soho New York on the 12th floor of an industrial building
column7: has become a true creative laboratory for the chef. Designed as a living space for gastronomy
column8: the professional kitchen opens onto a vast living room. All the furniture has been carefully chosen to fit perfectly into this new setting
column9: echoing the history of the location and occupying the space that welcomes guests in a warm
column10: contemporary mood. A vision of shared hospitality Yann Nury has taken up residence in a unique space designed by his friend Charles Zana
column11: a regular visitor to New York City. Nury was eager to collaborate with Zana who he felt understood his vision most clearly. Together they were able to create an authentically unique gathering place. The loft incorporates both of their personalities and philosophies to create a simple but sophisticated place that highlights the balance between the chef's work on ingredients
column12: textures and flavors and the architect's work on spaces
column14: all with a touch of modernity. Nury combines generosity with French-style traditions while Zana combines elegance with the enhancement of what exists. They wanted to create more than just an exceptional space or delicious food. Their approach is tinged with an unmistakable desire to create experiences. A symbiosis of the place’s architectural conception with the kitchen design To reveal the authenticity of the space
column15: Charles Zana chose to recapture and enhance the essence of this light-filled loft by leaving the structure and technology visible
column16: including the red and black industrial pipes that run the length of the ceiling. The original framework also revealed a magnificent skylight that was preserved. The harmony created by mixing the style of an American loft with the culture of French furniture gives the place its soul and makes it seem as if everything had been there for ages. At the center of the space
column17: the kitchen is the first area clients discover when they arrive. Conceived as a stage on which the chef and his teams give a culinary performance
column18: it has a Molteni gas stove surrounded by two huge work tables in gray Italian marble
column19: made from raw Ceppo di Gré stone. Guests can sit on Pierre Jeanneret stools placed around these two “islands” to comfortably watch the cooks’ ballet from a front-row perspective. A daring culinary experience in a cultivated space Contemporary creations mingle with 20th century furniture from various sources
column20: a symbol of the location’s eclecticism in the office adjoining the kitchen
column21: one can see the Trama tapestry designed by Charles Zana
column22: an armchair by Pierre Chapo and a selection of several pieces by Jean Touret made by the Ateliers de Marolles. Charles Zana selected a metal table designed for the Bank of France and manufactured by the Jansen workshops that takes its place in the dining room. Guests can also admire a Charlotte Perriand furniture unit reconstituted with 'diamond point' aluminum doors. At the back of the main room
column23: the Guillaume sofa in dark green mohair designed by Charles Zana is the centerpiece of the lounge area. Its soft lines invite guests to a moment of conviviality and relaxation. Various major contemporary art works inhabit the space
column24: including still lifes by Irving Penn and Robert Mapplethorpe as well as a Jean Dunand Art Deco gong that was once part of Andy Warhol's personal collection and a mushroom sculpture by Roxy Paine.";;;;;;"Adrian Gaut Courtesy Charles Zana";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/CHARLES%20ZANA_LA%20R%C3%89SIDENCE%2C%20NEW%20YORK%20%20%C2%A9%20ADRIAN%20GAUT%20%E2%80%93%20COURTESY%20CHARLES%20ZANA%20%281%29.jpg

column6: -73.9761903";;Retail;;;2022;"Laura Gonzalez was inspired by iconic depictions of Manhattan

column10: the towers of the San Remo building rising behind them. ""The final result strikes the perfect balance between elegant historical references and modern comfort

Fern;"Pascaline de Glo de Besses";Fern;"Kayu-Manis JL. Monumen TNI AU Jl. Donoloyo No.8
column8: 110.3897057";;"Cultural space";;;2019;"The experience of this workshop in the Kayumanis Company in Yogjakarta
column9: Indonesia
column10: was rewarding in learning about another production model. When mass production in Europe became industrialized and largely automated
column11: Kayumanis had about 115 workers in the workshops next to the design ofﬁce
column12: which itself had a dozen people. The teak wood is worked mainly by hand and with the use of remote-controlled portable tools. The assemblies follow the rules of joinery
column14: and are glued to meet the constraints of humidity since the furniture is exported to Europe mainly at the rate of one container per month. The major asset of this exchange for the company was to analyze the current trend in bathroom furniture in which they specialize. While teak wood is very solid
column15: the bathroom trend in Europe is for lightness. Materials such as terrazzo used for basins are also highly appreciated and the ""tropical"" mood persists in decoration. I therefore chose to work teak in the form of strips
column16: similar to the construction of boat decks. This results in a lighter effect than working with wood in its mass.";;;;;https://www.constructifs.com/pages/recherches/fern.php;"P.de Glo de Besses";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/Fern%2001.jpg

column1: Yaku;"Pascaline de Glo de Besses";Yaku;"Kobe
column4: a furniture collection in wood. 2017. I was selected by The French Institute to be artist in residence in Japan where I carried out research into the traditional art-form of Yaki-Sugi (burned wood). Following this experience
column5: I created an outdoor furniture collection inspired by this ancient Japanese method and also by Sashimono art work. Traditionally used for making the kabuki theater objects
column6: the technique consists of assembling wood pieces by jointing
column7: using neither glue nor nails. The stools were made by M. Matsuda
column8: a sashimono master based in Tokyo City.";;;;;https://www.constructifs.com/pages/recherches/yaku.php;"P.de Glo de Besses";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/Yaku%2001.jpg
column9: http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/Yaku%2002.jpg

column1: Pierre-Yves Rochon, Four Seasons Hotel Tianjin, 138 CHIFENG ROAD, 300041 HEPING DISTRICT, TIANJIN, CHINA;"PIERRE-YVES ROCHON";"Four Seasons Hotel Tianjin";"138 CHIFENG ROAD
column5: 117.20548";;Hotel;;;;"The Four Seasons Hotel Tianjin is an arrival to modern luxury on a grand scale
column6: and a reflection of the culture and prosperity of a highly cosmopolitan urban destination. The design of the hotel is inspired by the richness of Tianjin’s heritage
column7: the beauty of its surrounding landscapes
column8: and internationally influenced design styles and details. A sense of monumental grandeur is conveyed immediately upon arrival to the hotel’s triple-height lobby on Level 2. The proportions and volumes of this open
column9: airy space signal a departure from the busy pedestrian activity of surrounding streets and entry into a luxuriously elegant setting. Textures in wood and stone finishes echo the natural movements and colorations from regional landscapes and enhance the soothing
column10: warm ambiance that ushers guests into the lobby. Four Seasons Hotel Tianjin features 215 guest rooms and 44 suites.";;;;;;;"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/FSH%20Tianjin1.jpg

column1: Pierre-Yves Rochon, Grand Hotel Kronenhof, Via Maistra 130, 7504 Pontresina Switzerland  7504 Pontresina / St. Moritz · Schweiz;"PIERRE-YVES ROCHON";"Grand Hotel Kronenhof";"Via Maistra 130
column2: 7504 Pontresina Switzerland  7504 Pontresina / St. Moritz · Schweiz";"46.4934392
column3: 9.9013762";;Hotel;;;;"The perfect synergy has been created between grand hotel style and Alpine living in Grand Hotel Kronenhof. Rooms convey a contemporary feel reflecting the local landscape and nature. Palette of beige and peach complements traditional Engadine homes in the region while green accents bring the colors of wooded slopes inside. The local vernacular is respected and combined with international expectations blending to create luxurious and tranquil spaces. Grand Hotel Kronenhof features 112 guest rooms and suites.";;;;;;;"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/_DSC5589-2Voll.jpg

column1: Pierre-Yves Rochon, The Woodward Hotel, Quai Wilson 37, 1201 Geneva Switzerland;"PIERRE-YVES ROCHON";"The Woodward Hotel";"Quai Wilson 37
column3: 6.1522892";;Hotel;;;;"Nestled along the tranquil shores of Lake Geneva and surrounded by panoramic views of Mont Blanc
column4: The Woodward has been masterfully renovated and reimagined. The post-Haussmann style limestone building
column5: originally built in 1901 by French architect François Durel
column6: has since been carefully transformed by PYR into a modern classical five-star urban retreat. Guests can appreciate a sense of Geneva’s spirit and heritage through the thoughtfully crafted interior experience that honors its history
column8: and natural landscape. The classical body of the hotel has been balanced with contemporary European furnishings
column9: rich finishes
column10: and an elegant palette of creams
column12: and greens that echo the soothing tones of the surrounding mountains and lake. The Woodward has been designed as more than just a hotel
column13: as it is infused with the residential comfort of a “hôtel particulier”
column15: where no corner has gone untouched and every space has been given distinct character with bespoke furnishings
column17: and rare art collections. It is designed as a spectacular home on the lake
column18: with a mix of hand selected and personally curated items gathered throughout a life of travel. As Geneva’s first all-suite hotel
column19: guests can choose from luxurious and light-filled accommodations
column20: while enjoying restaurants by Michelin-starred L’Atelier de Joël Robuchon
column21: vegetable driven Le Jardinier by Alain Verzeroli
column22: and Le Spa Guerlain at The Woodward. The Woodward Geneva features 26 suites.";;;;;;;"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/Woodward1.jpg
column23: http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/Woodward2.jpg

column1: Grégoire Maisondieu, Restaurant Black Papper, Avenue de la gare, Meknès, Maroc;"Grégoire Maisondieu";"Restaurant Black Pepper";"Avenue de la gare
column4: -5.5331967";;Restaurant/bar;;;2020;"Black Pepper is a restaurant located in the city of Meknes (Morocco). The astonishing Moroccan sunlight
column5: filters through a dense network of louvers revealing the double height space and its materials. A mezzanine space
column9: behind a set of portholes. Downstairs
column10: bar and show kitchen are open on the space. Raw materials such as burned wood
column13: are the components of the envelope of the place. Leather
column15: marble (black marble with white veins from a local quarry)
column16: are the components of the finishes of the furniture
column17: bringing precision and refinement to the project. Green plants in huge terra cotta jars punctuate the space
column18: bringing sweetness and freshness to it.";;;;;;"Alexandre Chaplier";http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/_DPH5833-web_2.jpg

column1: Grégoire Maisondieu, Villa R, Rabat, Maroc;"Grégoire Maisondieu";"Villa R";"Rabat
column3: -6.8498129";;"Private residence";;;2018;"This is the main residence of a couple and their two children. The house is developed on three levels: Ground floor: reception
column4: living areas First floor: four beedrooms (family and guests). Basement: level of leisure (gym
column5: spa and cinema room) and services. They wanted a house that would allow them to make the most of the climate of Rabat
column6: an oceanic climate that allows you to be outdoors most of the year. A house with spaces where the family can meet
column7: but where everyone can also have their privacy. An easy to live house
column8: located in a new district of the Moroccan capital. Everything in the project has been done to erase the borders between interior and exterior
column9: and on the contrary bring continuity and fluidity to the spaces
column10: while avoiding a monumental aspect. Some examples: Interior / exterior continuity of the stone cladding of the walls on the ground floor and the basement. These walls are dressed in Tetouan Stone
column11: a moroccan stone of grey color
column12: quite textured and lively. (Tetouan is a city from the north mediterranean part of Morocco). For instance
column13: you can notice the large supporting wall extending over more than 35m from the swimming pool to the revisited Moroccan living room
column15: the fireplace and some contemporary artworks. Visual continuity of the ceiling between interior and exterior. In the dining room the ribbed pattern in wooden slats extends outside without interruption. The swimming pool slips under the covered terrace
column16: as close as possible to the living-room. The terrace decks runs alongside the pool and extends inside where it delimits the dining area. These different details mean that as soon as the large bay window (12 linear meters) is opened
column17: we no longer know where the border is between the inside and the outside. From the outside
column19: the mineral base (Tetouan stone) is perceived as a plinth on which is placed the level of the bedrooms
column20: imagined as an extruded box coated with white. From the garden
column21: you can see that large roof overhangs have been provided for protection from the sun. Upstairs
column23: the three family bedrooms communicate by a deep covered balcony. A system of retractable louvers allows you to adjust the degree of privacy and protection from the sun. In the basement
column24: the service areas and those linked to leisure activities (sports hall
column25: spa and cinema room) take their natural light by vegetated courtyards.";;;;;;"Alexandre Chaplier";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/11_villaR_1.jpg

Tricoire Design Studio, Les Jardins de Doha, Hermès;"TRICOIRE DESIGN STUDIO";"Les Jardins de Doha
column2: Hermès";"Place Vendôme Mall Lusail Faubourg - Gate 5
column5: 51.5207924";;Retail;;;2022;"To inaugurate the new Hermès'store in Doha
column7: Hermès wished to highlight Alexis Tricoire's universe
column8: committed to sustainable development. His proposal was to create an unexpected 2000m2 organic shape architecture with a succession of woven bamboo caves. He brought life with his biomimetic creations based on recycled industrial materials
column9: in continuity with his previous works made in iconic places. This setup
column10: in front of the Persic Golf
column11: gave the opportunity to Tricoire Design studio to share again his message beyond the europeens borders about the significance of recycling for nature's preservation. Guest were invited for a tremandous experience in this poetic setup enhanced by the talented light designer David Debrinay and the famous sound designer Alain Français.

column1: Each alcove of this surprising architecture accommodates an artistic installation based on recycled brushes. The journey starts under the orange light tree then invites us to pass under the up side down garden with his two giant anacondas facing three dancing birds flying over the hills landscape. In a second time we discover the Dome's constellation made of a recycled brushed. The main stage hosting the artists is framed by amazing fountains in sprays of metal shimmering blue.Then we turn over a cloudy landscape where we can observe a monkey
column2: peacefully sited on the land. The journey continues in a vault inhabited by luminous headdresses which leads us outside to a flock of mocking birds. From the terrace facing the sea
column3: behind the bamboo hills appears Doha'skyline.";;;;;https://alexistricoire.fr/portfolio-item/les-jardins-de-doha/;"© Tricoire Design Studio";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/les%20jardins%20de%20Doha%20%C2%A9%20Tricoire%20Design%20Studio%20meilleur%20qualit%C3%A9%201.jpg

column4: 120.71577";;Retail;;;2022;"The Chinese brand EP YAYING called on Franklin Azzi to design the new architectural concept of Shanghai

Reflecting the approach of the iconic label in the revival of luxury goods and Chinese heritage – the name EP YAYING means ‘pledge of quality’ – Franklin Azzi drew from Oriental cultural references and know-hows to design a minimal/maximal concept. This approach resulted in a program of spaces dedicated to experimentation and strolling
column9: and evolving uniquely with each new store. The architecture of the boutiques - in both new and existing buildings - focuses on transparency

column13: between the association of rough and smooth surfaces

column4: 139.7051782";;Retail;;;2004;"The “red bunker” offers a brutalist face to the Shibuya neighbourhood
column5: in Tokyo. Contrasting with the light and delicate Japanese buildings around it
column6: the project detaches from its context and introduces a new concept of architectural graft with an archetype of military construction. Differing from its surroundings by the absence of a front window display
column7: this UFO takes its inspiration from the tight volumes of military bunkers
column9: gun ports and baffles inside. For this project
column10: the issue is addressed in reverse: the red concrete façade acts as a city-wide landmark that can be seen from afar. The point is to catch the eye of the passersby with this unexpected formalism in the heart of Tokyo: the opacity of the façade gives off so little information on the building that it arouses people’s curiosity.";;;;;http://www.franklinazzi.fr/en/projects/bali-barret-01-red-bunker-tokyo;©SAZABY;"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/FAA_BALI%20BARRET%2001_r%C3%A9alisation_HD_%C2%A9%20Sazaby_01_BD.jpg

column3: Mrs. Bali Barret is part of the French Haute Couture House Hermès
column4: where she took over as the new creative director for women's universe of silk and textile. Prior to that
column5: she created her own brand: Bali Barret. The ‘Red Military Tent’ accommodates her second store
column6: hidden behind a large tarpaulin. In addition to being unusual
column7: this project appeals for its manufacturing process – a breakthrough from the traditional store design codes. To comply with the function it houses
column8: this architecture uses an appropriate design language – that of textile creation. In the same way as a seamstress would reconstruct a piece of clothing from a pattern
column9: the contractors were provided with a facade pattern of the tent. The waxed canvas is tensioned with natural leather straps and spanned on a metal framework. The base is weighted down with sandbags. To enter the tent
column10: you walk through a timber entrance lobby and then discover an interior space with ecru walls. Both the opacity of the facade and the lack of information of this unexpected formalism are a way to attract the curious of Downtown Tokyo. It is the purpose that the project was intended to serve – for six years
column11: the store had become a new urban landmark.";;;;;http://www.franklinazzi.fr/en/projects/bali-barret-store-02-red-military-tent;©SAZABY;http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/FAA_BALI%20BARRET%2002_%C2%A9%20SAZABY_01_BD.jpg

column1: AW² , Shirvan Métisse Doha, 7 La Croisette, Porto Arabia Drive, Doha, Qatar;AW²;"Shirvan Métisse Doha";"7 La Croisette
column5: 51.540227";;Restaurant/bar;;;;"Shirvan Métisse Doha is located in the prominent Pearl Marina
column6: amidst high-end shops and restaurants aimed at local Qataris and tourists. The 600sqm
column7: 140-person capacity restaurant sits across two floors and includes a lounge area and bar
column8: a large dining hall and expansive terraced areas for diners to enjoy views across the marina and the Doha skyline. Shirvan Métisse Doha has been designed to simulate a journey on the Silk Route
column9: through the culinary traditions of the various countries that are encountered. AW2 used textures
column11: materials and lighting to create a series of different atmospheres to give guests the sense of moving through various environments as they experience the different spaces in the restaurant. At the entrance to the restaurant
column14: combined with dimmed and indirect lighting creates a sense of privacy. Intricate lattice screens continue to feature on the internal walls
column15: aiming to direct guests towards the main dining hall or the mezzanine lounge and bar on the top floor. Elemental materials including timber
column17: marble and leather are used throughout. The central space of the restaurant is octagonal and double-height. It features a show kitchen allowing guests to see Benallal’s team at work. Olive trees and spices displayed on a marble table recall the colourful food markets of the region. Arched floor-to-ceiling windows open towards the marina where additional outdoor seating is provided. Outdoor dining areas are shaded by wooden pergolas and olive trees. The furniture has been bespoke designed by AW2. The black granite floor contrasts with grey marbles and brass inserts in the tables. Bold ornamental elements such as mesh pendant lights along with an openwork brass Yemeni pattern cover the ceiling and create a play of light and shadows throughout. Alternated carved wooden panels and mineral rendered walls enclose the space and reflect the light across the room. Reda Amalou & Stéphanie Ledoux
column18: Partners at AW² commented: “Shirvan Restaurant is an insightful study of experiential space design in which the architecture and the interiors aim to enhance the sensorial experience already provided by chef Akrame Benallal’s phenomenal cuisine. It creates a place for people to absorb Qatar’s culture
column19: intertwining tradition with contemporary design.” ©Architect: AW² - Reda Amalou & Stéphanie Ledoux";;;;;https://www.aw2.com/projets/restaurants/shirvan-metisse-doha-qatar/;"Mikael Bénard";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/AW2_Shirvan-Metisse-Doha_Credit-Mikael-B%C3%A9nard_1.jpg
column20: http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/AW2_Shirvan-Metisse-Doha_Credit-Mikael-B%C3%A9nard_2.jpg

Humbert & Poyet, Florida, Monte-Carlo, Monaco;"HUMBERT & POYET";Florida;"Monte-Carlo
column3: 7.4266436";;"Private residence";;;;"We designed a great duplex in Monaco
column4: the interior of which became the backdrop for the luxury art collection. We had a beautiful carte blanche. The only guidelines: a contemporary flat in H&I style. That it be a family flat as well as a reception flat. A project that works on the enhancement of the owners' art collection. Our main starting point of the design of this duplex was the owners extensive and diverse collection of art. We wanted to balance the playful and bold elements of their collection with a soft and neutral palette to subtly draw the eye to the artworks while maintaining a contemporary yet sophisticated mood. In order to highlight the works
column6: designing new patterns and mouldings in the process. For example
column7: in the living room we created a freestanding L-shaped shelving unit in front of the windows to display the owner’s eclectic collection of smaller sculptural pieces while allowing for the natural light to pass into the space. A real game between our architecture and their collection. The collectors chose the pieces according to the designed space. It was quite playful because everything was not defined in advance. It was like a journey of sensitivity between interior design and art. A real dialogue to highlight both.";;;;;;"Francis Amiand";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/HP-Duplex-14-15-5427_FA.jpg
column9: http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/HP-Duplex-14-15-5534_FA.jpg"

column3: -16.57579";;"Cultural space";;;2020;"The House of UNO is an outstanding project located in the new incoming ministries district Diamniadio
column5: in Senegal. Initiated by the Senegalese government
column6: the challenge consisted of gathering the 34 UN agencies scattered in Dakar in a new iconic and radiant building. Its shape reminds a water mill or a sun which rays evoke concentration but also radiation and influences. It appears as a white circular volume with seven radiant wings. The spatial conception leads to a strong identity: the combination of independence and collaboration for the agencies in its inside and the symbol of a powerful decision center in a brand-new urban landscape. The landscape on the surrounding will assure the link between this not so common shape and the urban plan. By the uses of local material for grounds and vegetation
column7: the garden will create the link between the local soil and the international sphere. In its conception
column8: its construction and future running the House of UNO as a public building will promote exemplarity in terms of energy and accessibility. The spatial modulation of the program echoes with the shape : The official spaces will be situated in the very heart of the edifice: amphitheater and reception spaces will host international conferences
column9: seminaries and debates. This central activity will be sustained by a ring of public and common spaces such as informatic support
column12: restauration areas and so on. Connected to the shared circle
column15: will take place in the rays
column16: as a symbol of spreading UNO’s values.";;;;;http://www.wilmotte.com/fr/projet/499/maison-des-nations-unies;;"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/01_Vue%20aerienne%20nuit_0.png

column5: in charge of museography and design
column6: were appointed for Adelaide Contemporary - renamed Tarrkarri - Centre for first nations culture - international design competition organized by Arts South Australia and Malcolm Reading Consultants. Tarrkarri is a new museum showcasing the past
column7: present and future of Aboriginal culture and its artistic practices across all disciplines. The design of the building stems from the Aboriginal conception of the elements that connect us to a place: earth
column8: land and sky. Lower level galleries and terraced landscapes are carved into the earth
column9: providing indoor exhibition spaces that integrate the museum's visible
column10: accessible and dynamic reserves with the performance spaces and space dedicated to traditional Aboriginal welcome ceremonies. The upper galleries break western conventions by introducing exhibition spaces that vary in size
column12: and offer unique views of the sky

column5: Joanna Spiteri Staines and Alberto Miceli-Farrugia — won the competition for the Gozo Museum in the island capital Victoria (Gozo - Malta). In 2018
column6: NIDUM called upon Studio Adrien Gardère to join their team as lead museographer
column7: exhibition designer and artistic consultant. The new museum comprises the extension and rehabilitation of the Ninu Cremona Boys Lyceum
column8: an iconic piece of modernist architecture designed in the 1950s by architect Joseph Huntingford. In 2019
column9: the discovery of an extensive ancient quarry
column10: dating back to the Punic and Roman periods on the site

column1: Jouin Manku , La Maison Van Cleef & Arpels' Seoul , Van Cleef & Arpels' Maison Seoul, 441, Apgujeong-ro, Gangnam-gu, Séoul, Corée du Sud;"Jouin Manku & Patrick Jouin iD";"La Maison Van Cleef & Arpels Seoul";"Van Cleef & Arpels Maison Seoul
column9: Hong Kong and Tokyo
column10: the Jouin Manku studio has completed Van Cleef & Arpels’ maison in Seoul. For this new project
column11: Patrick Jouin and Sanjit Manku were entrusted with the entire architectural conception of the building
column12: the interior architecture and the design of every final detail. A complete project and a new opportunity to share a fascination for the world
column13: as the studio celebrates its sixteenth year of collaboration with the exceptional French maison de haute joaillerie. Van Cleef & Arpels is driven by savoir-faire and a demand for excellence
column14: but also by culture and heritage
column15: and continues to play an important role in the development of the decorative arts. Under the management of Nicolas Bos
column16: we see a brand that is heavily involved in a range of cultural activities
column17: from commissioning dance performances to sponsoring a school of jewellery arts. It is this commitment that has fuelled the Jouin Manku studio. These cultural alliances are interwoven throughout Van Cleef & Arpels’ commercial activity
column18: ensuring the company’s status as a powerful purveyor of dreams. This project seeks to offer Korea a Van Cleef & Arpels showcase
column19: exposing its level of craftsmanship
column20: its heritage and taste for the arts and culture
column21: as well as expressing the links between the east and the west
column22: embracing and celebrating Korean culture. No question of bringing in ideas of style
column23: but rather of teasing out a sophisticated blend
column25: contemporary and craftsmanship. Jouin Manku has put its vision of European and occidental architecture to the test by endeavouring to embrace Korean ideas
column26: reflecting the country’s vast cultural wealth in the project. Advocating the spirit of opening up to the world in order to find our natural place in a new ecosystem. “With the creation of this new Maison
column27: we are celebrating ever stronger bonds with this country
column28: known for a long tradition of craftsmanship that echoes the values espoused by Van Cleef & Arpels. Indeed
column29: the boutique was designed to form a union between the French jewelry tradition and Korean cultural heritage
column30: and to nurture this dialogue for years to come.” Nicolas Bos- President and CEO of Van Cleef & Arpels “This project offered us the opportunity to imagine a whole new building
column31: a structure that would establish Van Cleef & Arpels as a prominent feature in the Seoul landscape. Over five levels
column32: we designed a dreamlike natural decor with spaces suited to hosting artistic functions – exhibitions and conferences – along an itinerary in which lively spaces alternate with intimate islands of tranquility.” Sanjit Manku & Patrick Jouin - Studio Jouin Manku";;;;;;"©Yongjoon Choi";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/Van%20Cleef%20%26%20Arpels%20Seoul%20Maison_Studio%20Jouin%20Manku%20%C2%A9Yongjoon%20Choi%202022_5.jpg

column4: 6.1426684";;Restaurant/bar;;;2019;"The challenge for EL'LE Interior stories architects was to allow the various restaurants to meet strict Integration criteria according to the city districts In which they were located. The target with Infinity was to energize a new district and be a meeting place for the people working In the area.";;;;;;"EL'LE Interior";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/recup_image_1653923175.jpg

column1: ELLE INTERIOR STORIES, Casino 2000, 5 Rue Flammang, 5618 Mondorf-les-Bains, Luxembourg;"EL'LE Interior Stories";"Casino 2000";"5 Rue Flammang
column5: in the middle of the slot machines area
column6: offers an incomparable moment of relaxation. Inspired by the circus atmosphere
column7: you can take a break and chat for a while over a drink or a delicious snack. The challenge was to completely transform this area while allowing it to continue to integrate perfectly with the old identity of the place. The gastronomic restaurant ""Les Roses"" has been redesigned to be more elegant and modern. The interior architecture has been designed to support the sober and modern cuisine of its new Chef
column8: and the colors and materials have been chosen to match the aesthetics of the dishes. The ""Dome""
column9: with its specific ventilation system
column10: features a circulation area for smokers and is adorned with materials that are at once eco-responsible
column11: sober and practical. The ""Manège"" has a resolutely upscale identity that creates a world distinct from the rest of the Casino
column12: and houses the gaming tables and a cocktail bar with V.I.P. accents.";;;;;;"EL'LE Interior";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/recup_image_1653923174.jpg

column1: KNGB, ZX living store, Taipei, Taiwan;KNGB;"ZX living store";"Taipei
column3: 121.5654268";;Retail;;;2020;"Our collaboration with Zx living started following their 1st participation in Maison et Objet in 2018. We made floor lamps in natural oak and light grey fabrics to meet the Taiwanese demand. We use subtle elegance to illuminate home and building interiors with our range of high-end lighting solutions. KNGB's lampshades are handcrafted in our workshop and the various stands and lighting accessories are made from premium raw materials including oak
column5: metal and wool flannel - all sourced locally from the best artisans and producers in the region. This is what seduced the Zx living team.";;;;;;kngb;http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/27e62e91-a0e9-441a-8bb8-1fa9e4255c85-votre_visuel_n_6-fa%C3%A7ade-zx-living.jpg

column1: ELLE INTERIOR STORIES, Jewelry Box, 103-105, Avenue de la Faïencerie, L-1511 Luxembourg;"EL'LE Interior Stories";"Jewelry Box";"103-105
column4: 6.1156275";;"Private residence";;;2019;"Located on the top floor of an old building
column7: was equipped with all essential functions. Our client fell In love with this property because of Its location
column8: with an exceptional view of the whole city of Luxembourg. We decided to transform It Into a hotel style suite with comfortable materials
column9: mixing nordic softness and Italian warmth. The bedroom area can be visible or hidden by a tinted glass partition.";;;;;;"EL'LE Interior";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/recup_image_1653923173.jpg

column1: ELLE INTERIOR STORIES, Cocottes Belval, 6 Av. des Hauts-Fourneaux, 4362 Esch-sur-Alzette, Luxembourg;"EL'LE Interior Stories";"Cocottes Belval";"6 Av. des Hauts-Fourneaux
column4: 5.9499256";;Restaurant/bar;;;2019;"The challenge for EL'LE Interior stories architects was to allow the various restaurants to meet strict Integration criteria according to the city districts In which they were located. The challenge here was to fully integrate the restaurant into the historic site in which it was to take place: the blast furnaces of Belval are classified as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.";;;;;;"EL'LE Interior";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/recup_image_1653923173_0.jpg

column3: 6.1255507";;Office;;;2019;"At the heart of Europe for over 125 years
column4: SOCIETE GNERALE Luxembourg Is a multi-expert banking group located In the Grand Duchy. Based on the code of conduct and the values of the SOCIETE GENERALE GROUP -team spirit
column6: Innovation and responsibility- The EL'LE Interior stories architects have redesigned the premises In order to offer the bank's numerous employees colorful spaces on a human scale and with diverse functionalities.";;;;;;"EL'LE Interior";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/recup_image_1653923169.jpg

column5: the design was inspired by the surrounding natural elements
column7: stone and landscape of Greece. Craftsmanship and art are underlined in the space. The tabletops are made of ceramic tiling bearing a painted design. The furniture composed of natural woods in walnut and iroko. The bar and lounge feature a central bar with a carved pattern

column9: gym The Wink concept sees AW² move towards a new architectural typology in the hospitality realm – the medium-rise urban hotel. The Wink brand is directly born out of the evolution that the hotel industry is currently undergoing. Wink brings us into this new era with its pop culture energy and blended spaces where accommodation
column10: work and leisure cohabit. This twenty-first century hospitality product is targeted at a new generation of traveller
column11: one that is constantly connected and seeking a hotel experience that rhymes with their epoque. The Wink brand has been designed by AW² to attract this new hotel clientele. The Wink hotels are fashionable urban destinations where the next generation of influencers will go to stay
column13: enjoy Vietnamese cuisine or simply use their laptops in the coworking spaces. The project brings Vietnamese street life into the lobby and public areas of the hotel with street life-inspired furniture designed by AW² and an interior design that resonates with the outside urban environment. A specific colour palette has been created for the brand by AW² and can be found throughout the hotel – from the scale of the bespoke cushion fabrics to the sunshades on the facades. The 237 hotel rooms have been laid out over eleven floors. They are conceived to be efficient in space requirements
column15: creative pods that provide the guests with all comforts in a stylish

column18: financial return and construction feasibility. In this way
column19: the Wink brand is a contrast of traditional style with modern forward-thinking originality. It aims to deliver vibrant
column20: innovative experiences for all its guests and users. The Wink brand is the transmission of AW²’s savoir-faire in resort architecture to an urban context and will roll out across Vietnam over several sites in the years to come.";;;;;;AW²;"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/c4cc49da-4c45-4568-8ac2-1e1eeb895df5-votre_visuel_projet_n_4-G-G_01.jpg
