column1: Stephane Parmentier, Casa Minotto, Pointe Milou, 97133, Saint-Barthélemy;"Agence Stéphane Parmentier";"Casa Minotto";"Pointe Milou
Nazak Design, 1904 Beaux ArtsBuilding Manhattan UWS, 344 W 72nd St, New York, NY 10023, États-Unis;"Nazak Design";"1904 Beaux ArtsBuilding Manhattan UWS";"344 W 72nd St
column5: -73.9864464";;"Private residence";;;2018;"My husband Bill and I were ready for a change. I was looking for something large and rambling
column6: perhaps on the East Side as a change of direction
column7: and ideally in “estate condition” requiring a total rebuild. That would be more work but a labor of love as it would provide the opportunity for re-expression of every detail
column8: from the layout to the last ornamental touch. But
column9: another accident—in the apartment hunt
column10: I came across a 1900 Beaux Art building on the opposite side of Manhattan
column11: the Upper West Side. It was as close as it comes to a Paris building on a New York avenue
column12: and I fell in love. The available space combined three apartments into a single unit with four bedrooms
column15: and an open kitchen. The bones weren’t just good—they were spectacular. But the floorplan needed to be rearranged and the interior aesthetics updated. So rather than a gut renovation
column16: we focused on the adjustments and finishing touches necessary to restore the space to its former glory: new doors
column19: new fixtures
column20: new millwork. Transforming the dark fourth bedroom into an inviting library was one of the major challenges. We achieved that by breaking open the wall and replacing it with a wafer-thin
column21: high-gloss navy-blue door that could slide shut (to ensure quiet and privacy when necessary) or open widely (to allow the light from the street to tumble in). The custom-built door was far too large for the 1904-sized elevator bank
column22: and so had to be delivered in pieces and assembled in the apartment. Another challenge was the kitchen. In the plan we inherited
column23: the cooking space opened to the dining room
column24: with a shared marble counter between the rooms. Open kitchens can be wonderful
column25: of course
column26: but I felt the restrained elegance of the building called for slightly more formality. But the marble countertop that extending out from the kitchen presented a puzzle—cutting it was risky
column27: but leaving it jutting out into the dining room was out of the question. We solved the puzzle by sealing up the original opening
column28: installing modern floor-to-ceiling cabinetry on the dining room with two sections divided by the white marble line of the counter
column29: finished in anthracite steel. And to brighten the kitchen we added a brushed brass backsplash as well as a row of functional upper cabinets. As is so often the case
column30: the final finishes weave the elements together. Herringbone wood floors were refinished to show natural oak;closet doors in the large dressing areas were dressed in gray panels
column31: handles and fixtures throughout the space feature specialty brass from a favorite London vendor. We finished with a mix of contemporary French and Italian furnishings and decorative objects
column32: designed to marry contemporary European style with a uniquely and traditionally Manhattan space.";;;;;;"Azita Panahpour";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/a29bca6a-bb17-42db-abb4-d04c387e28c2-votre_visuel_projet_n_2-thumbnail-1.jpg

column3: lockdown provided great food for thought for the interior designer. This new creation is a manifesto for “living better”

column9: the space is intimate and feminine

column13: nor an end. It is a space to isolate
column15: and awaken one’s senses to a benevolent nature

column1: Aurelien Chen, Chinese liquor boutique hotel, Yan'an, Shaanxi, Chine;"AURELIEN CHEN";"Chinese liquor boutique hotel";"Yan'an
column4: 109.48978";;Retail;;;2020;"A sensorial journey through the making of traditional Chinese wine. In China
column5: alcohol is made from cereals seeds
column6: following the same process for centuries. After a careful study of this process
column7: we created a specific architectural scenography that gives the visitor the opportunity to experience the process of making Chinese wine. At the entrance
column8: various seeds are placed in Plexiglas tubes to create a vibrant screen with a huge pattern. In the rooms
column9: seeds were directly integrated inside the paint of the walls
column10: resulting in a very specific texture. More generally
column11: warm tones and shades of brown and ochre remind of the topic of the seeds. Alcohol is traditionally placed in ceramic jars for fermentation. They are usually made of very dark ceramic with shades of purple or dark red. When entering the entrance lobby
column12: visitor stands on a transparent carpet made of glass. Underneath lie a series of jars that are half buried
column13: giving the illusion of ancient jars. This carpet extends to the outdoor space and becomes a water fountain. The sequences of circulation become obvious. Calm and elegant atmospheres
column14: use of black marble for the front desk and of black wood for furniture
column15: remind of black ceramic jars. Vegetal materials are often used to fasten the fermentation process. They are compacted and stored as bricks. We used these vegetal bricks to create the counter of the bar
column16: which gives an olfactive experience to the user. The countertop is made of custom terrazzo
column17: with pieces of alcohol glass bottles integrated in it. Pieces of furniture
column19: as well as the plaited fabrics used for wall and ceiling covering
column20: remind of the traditional tools that are used for the making of alcohol: wicker baskets and sieves
column21: etc. Outdoor spaces are part of this sensorial course
column22: creating a continuity between interior and exterior. The installation located in the main courtyard reminds the transformation of liquid
column23: from steam to condensation in drop of alcohol. Collaborator : Zhijian Workshop : Aurelien Chen (lead) + Wang Ke Yao";;;;;;"Aurelien Chen";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/f5ec10ca-62cc-4e43-bcec-d3ba5aacd9bd-votre_visuel_projet_n_4-Aurelien-Chen-B%20%281%29_0.jpg

column1: Nazak Design, Prewar Manhattan Upper West Side, 685 West End Avenue, New York, NY, 10025;"Nazak Design";"Prewar Manhattan Upper West Side";"685 West End Avenue
column5: -73.9748073";;"Private residence";;;2015;"One of the great and fun challenges of interior design in New York is to turn small spaces into big ones—projects we sometimes call “Mission Impossible.” Because of high real estate prices and scarce inventory for desirable pre-war buildings
column6: Manhattanites are forever trying to cram more into less. So when one lovely client called to ask how could she turn her “Classic Six”—a 1927 two bedroom apartment—into a four bedroom layout sufficient to meet the needs of her growing family
column7: it was just another day on the job. The building had great bones: high ceilings and large airy rooms. The challenge was to somehow create two additional rooms with the same floor space
column8: without sacrificing the elegant flow. We settled on a plan to borrow space from the formal dining room (which was outsized by contemporary standards)
column9: shave a bit of territory from one of the pre-existing bedrooms
column10: reconfigure large but inefficient walk in closet and enlarging the maid’s room
column12: slightly redirect the main corridor in the apartment
column13: and from those adjustments conjure a third and fourth bedroom—each small but comfortable
column14: serviced by a shared bathroom and modern closets. Even better
column15: we were able to maintain the couple’s master bedroom in its original generous size
column16: update the en suite bath with Carrera marble and double sinks
column17: and—using just a bit more of the recovered dining room space—create a spacious walk-in closet for the master suite. The bright and large living room was updated but retained its grand and welcoming proportions. To replace the old dining room
column18: we designed a gallery at the mouth of the corridor that functioned as overflow entertaining space as well as a dining area. The renovated kitchen featured upgraded appliances
column19: Italian tile work and a stainless steel backsplash. Along the way
column20: we updated the floor
column21: the AC and AV system and installed modern hidden storage throughout. Herringbone Russian white oak floors throughout brightly tied all the elements together. By putting every inch of the floor plan to work
column22: we transformed the apartment from two bedrooms to four
column23: improved the flow
column24: enhanced the natural light in every room
column25: all the while maintaining the traditional elegance of the pre-war building.";;;;;;"Scott Morris";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/a29bca6a-bb17-42db-abb4-d04c387e28c2-votre_visuel_n_3-T-4669.jpg

column15: color and fragrance of frangipani flowers
column16: this creation also reflects the beauty
column17: spirit and dynamism of Singapore. column4: 109.48978";;"Cultural space";;;2020;"A sensorial journey through the making of traditional Chinese wine: alcohol fermentation stage. In China
column5: alcohol is made from cereals seeds
column6: following the same process for centuries. After a careful study of this process
column7: we created a specific architectural scenography that gives the visitor the opportunity to experience the process of making Chinese wine. Outdoor spaces are part of this sensorial course
column8: creating a continuity between interior and exterior. When entering the entrance lobby
column9: visitor stands on a transparent carpet made of glass. Underneath lie a series of jars that are half buried
column10: giving the illusion of ancient jars. This carpet extends to the outdoor space
column11: reminding of traditional distilleries where so many jars were put together on the ground that they would recover the entire space and become like a carpet. At the back of the yard
column12: the jars emerge from the ground and become a fountain. The water that runs along the ceramic emphasizes the material. Collaborator : Zhijian Workshop : Aurelien Chen (lead) + Wang Ke Yao and Jiang Ze (Landscape design)";;;;;;"Aurelien Chen

column5: alcohol is made from cereals seeds
column6: following the same process for centuries. After a careful study of this process
column7: we created a specific architectural scenography that gives the visitor the opportunity to experience the process of making Chinese wine. Outdoor spaces are part of this sensorial course
column8: creating a continuity between interior and exterior. The installation located in the main courtyard reminds the transformation of liquid
column9: from steam to condensation in drop of alcohol. It is a monumental jar. Yet
column10: it is delicately floating between ground floor and basement. It becomes a landmark
column11: highly visible from every interior space
column12: especially from the labyrinthine basement. Steam goes out from the upper part of the gigantic jar
column13: then drops run down the stainless steel bars
column14: and end up in a perfect circle at the ground. Collaborator : Zhijian Workshop : Aurelien Chen (lead) + Wang Ke Yao and Jiang Ze (Landscape design)";;;;;;"Li Xin & Aurelien Chen";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/f5ec10ca-62cc-4e43-bcec-d3ba5aacd9bd-visuel_5-Aurelien-Chen-Installation-I-Boutique-hotel-1.jpg

column1: Aw², Kasiiya Papagayo, Kasiiya Papagayo, Costa Rica;AW²;"Kasiiya Papagayo";"Kasiiya Papagayo
column6: communal spaces Kasiiya is not a hotel. Kasiiya is part of nature. Built on timber platforms from natural materials
column7: it leaves no scar on its landscape. From the very beginning
column8: the conservation of the tropical forest has been paramount. Our intention throughout the project was not to have minimal impact on the environment
column9: but zero. This project in Costa Rica has propelled architecture and the boutique hotel experience into a new dimension
column11: a new ecology. Architecture and nature can live in symbiosis rather than in opposition
column12: without one trying to gain ground over the other.Kasiiya is the application of this concept. The project was completed without cutting down a single tree and without the use of concrete and nails. Meticulously positioned amidst 123 acres of wild landscape
column13: our concept stems from the idea that there should be no frontier between architecture and the surrounding wilderness
column14: between the inside and the outside. This Kasiiya Papagayo is composed on the scale of a village
column15: made up of clusters of tents
column16: densifying the habitat in some areas and then letting nature take full rein in others. Constructed from mainly local natural materials
column17: each tent offers its guests total comfort with bespoke furniture designed by AW². Each tent is carefully orientated to reconnect with nature alone. Inside the tents
column18: the camping mindset continues. The demountable character of the tentes
column19: which makes it possible at any time to make the place the same as on arrival
column20: is what gives this project this eco-responsible aspect.";;;;;;"Sergio Pucci";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/c4cc49da-4c45-4568-8ac2-1e1eeb895df5-votre_visuel_projet_n_1-AW2_Kasiiya-Papagayo_Exterior-view-1_Cr.jpg

column1: Nazak Design, Susan Falk, The Hamptons, État de New York, États-Unis;"Nazak Design";"Susan Falk";"The Hamptons
column4: -72.338516235352";;"Private residence";;;2019;"This project began in 2018 when a New York City couple approached me to help reimagine their traditional/classic cottage in Amagansett
column5: among the most rustic and authentic of the “Hamptons” areas in Long Island. Built in 1998
column6: the home was intended to fit seamlessly into the local architectural style. This traditional style served the family well as the children grew up. But with the kids now out on their own
column7: the couple wanted to update their home in anticipation of a new phase in life and a more contemporary lifestyle. The clients flirted with the idea of starting from scratch
column9: but ultimately determined that the home’s location and views — just a stone’s throw from untamed Atlantic beaches —could not be replicated. So we decided to undertake a ground-up rebuild. And we’d have to do it fast—the client did not want to miss even a single summer. That left us about eight months
column11: to complete the renovation. The challenge was to create a more open flow in the interiors adding increased light and airiness and taking advantage of the home’s privileged seaside location. Unnecessary doors closed off the public/entertaining rooms downstairs;thresholds were low and narrow
column12: and some rooms were barely used. With these obstacles removed and reconfigured
column13: a new and easy flow emerged. The furniture were sourced through local or international vendors
column15: with a mix of contemporary and vintage. Upstairs where the family bedrooms were situated needed more dramatic updating. We needed to rethink the entire floor plan. Five small bedrooms were transformed to three generous ones
column16: each with an ensuite bathroom. The master bedroom was doubled in size and moved to the front of the house to take advantage of the ocean views. A double door would separate their bedroom with the en suite bathroom and walk in closet for a desired privacy. Their daughters’ rooms
column17: at the opposite end of the hallway
column18: were enlarged and en suite bathrooms were added. Removing one bedroom and repurposing the space as a cozy sitting room (with fireplace) was a bonus. And having the plumbing lines and a corner space
column19: we added a full bath in case of unexpected guests! Then we had to address the connective tissue
column20: where upstairs meets downstairs. The landing at the top of the stairs was reconfigured into an open library with floor to ceiling bookcases and seating. Perhaps the real coup was converting a portion of the attic into an open air patio area with broad water views. To access the space via the central staircase beginning on the ground level
column21: we designed a wood and steel railing which zigzags up to the third floor. The key to our successful outcome was our close collaboration
column23: flexibility and patience. The ultimate sign that the approach worked? Our delighted clients can’t spend enough time in their new space.";;;;;;"Trio Giovan";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/a29bca6a-bb17-42db-abb4-d04c387e28c2-votre_visuel_projet_n_1-206-Bluff-Rd.interiors-42-_3.jpg
column25: http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/a29bca6a-bb17-42db-abb4-d04c387e28c2-votre_visuel_projet_n_1-Bluff-Road-Living-Room-01_061-3-_3.png"

column5: 2022";"Urban space/Transportation";;;2020;"The environmental strategy behind the 2 new masterplans on 2 former railway wastelands in Milan is to first set up two environmental filters (Limpidarium)
column6: one cleaning the air at Farini
column7: i.e. an 18-hectare park filtering the hot and polluted air coming with the prevailing wind from the South-West to the South-East
column8: and the other of 15 hectares cleaning the water at San Cristoforo to produce a natural swimming pool. The volumetry of the new district in Farini lets the refreshing convective winds pass through

column10: without depending on a minimum investment. Urban planning regulations are based on albedo

column5: 2022";Restaurant/bar;;;2019;"Once a design has contributed defining a brand
column6: growth poses an interesting challenge for architects. How does one convey an established identity and familiarity of brand while refraining from copy pasting previous designs over to a new location? Boqueria in Chicago is located in the West Loop
column7: in the former industrial & meatpacking neighborhood of Fulton-Randolf District which is being currently gentrified. Most buildings
column9: have retained an industrial look: large open floor plates with columns. Because these spaces are predominantly horizontal in proportion
column10: our approach was to layer the information so the design in its totality would provide a clear understanding of how it is organized. Prevailing materials are wood and black tiles
column11: both not only reminiscent of the original Boqueria but also because of the feelings associated with them. One taking on a nice patina over time
column12: the other providing a feeling of permanence & protection throughout the space. column5: 2022";"Urban space/Transportation";;;2019;"An installation by Aurelien Chen recreating an ethereal and abstract version of a traditional Chinese landscape. Above all else
column6: this installation is a landmark placed by the roadside to draw the attention to the entrance of the Dragon Mountain Natural site (Zhulong Shan)
column7: a typical example of « Shanshui » traditional Chinese landscape composed by mountains
column9: clouds and water. There are three different sequences of approach and just as many levels of perception in this installation. While approaching the site from the street
column10: a vibrant mountain composed by 200 inox poles subtly appears in the distance. With speed
column11: the poles become a single surface and the effects created by the different materials composing the poles reveal the shape of a new mountain. While the visitor moves closer
column12: he discovers a miniature landscape in which he can move and stroll. The poles become a forest;a black marble river invites the visitor to walk towards the real mountain standing out against the horizon. The canopies placed above the visitor’s head to represent clouds
column13: turn out to be mirrors. In this peaceful setting
column14: urban life goes on reflecting itself on the mirror canopies and on the surface of the poles. The perforations on the mirror panels create an interplay of light and shadow marking the passing of time. At night
column15: thousands of stars appear on the poles
column17: and give shape to a mountain vibrant with light. Overall planning : Urban and rural planning and design institute of CSCEC Design support : Zhou ZhiPeng (parametric design)

column11: Let`s Meet at Tanabata” exhibition. On Tanabata day
column12: Japanese people write their hopes and dreams on colored pieces of paper and hang them on a bamboo branch in hopes that their wishes will come true. Emmanuelle reimagines this tradition by extracting the sense of Tanabata onto the floating words. She chose the simplest written alphabet children first learn “hiragana”
column13: composed of 46 different characters. In Tanabata
column14: hiragana are used to express the hopes and dreams. The universe created by these floating hiraganas evokes an emotion through its stillness and its endlessness. By condensing the essence of the word itself
column15: it derives to the emotion. The swaying hiragana form and symbolize the wishful colored pieces of paper swaying from the bamboo branch. The installation was composed of approximately 140
column17: regularly aligned in three dimensional grids. Visitors could wonder inside the colorful space filled with hiraganas to share the sense of stillness. Sections of the installation were removed
column18: creating paths that cut through the installation. Walking through the countless numbers of hiraganas
column19: words gradually come to mind…As part of Emmanuelle’s ""100 colors"" installation series
column20: the layers of hiraganas were colored in 100 shades of colors
column21: creating a colorful Universe of Words. Within those characters
column22: CALPIS bottles figures were lost and could be found along with the CALPIS logo
column23: adding playfulness to the installation.";;;;;;"Daisuke Shima";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/emmanuelle%20moureaux%20architecture%20%2B%20design_Universe%20of%20Words_Installation_%C2%A9Daisuke%20Shima%20%281%29.jpg

Their main challenge was to transform the industrial unit into a XXI century design studio while enhancing its 1930s-building structure and historical heritage.";;;;;;;"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/ID%20Real_1_0.jpg

column1: Restaurant/bar Dariel Studio Lady Bund Renovated;"Dariel Studio & Maison Dada";"Lady Bund Renovated";"No.22
column7: Lady Bund restaurant and lounge was recently renovated into a luxurious and exclusive club hosted in the upscale Bund 22 building. Following their original collaboration with Thomas Dariel in 2014
column8: the owners of Lady Bund were completely taken by the French designer’s tasteful
column9: yet unconventional blending of both Chinese and French cultures in the restaurant’s design. Without hesitation
column10: they invited him back for their latest renovation endeavour.";;;;;;;"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/Lady%20Bund%20renovated_1_0.jpg

column1: Hotel Dariel Studio Nanxun Blossom Hill;"Dariel Studio & Maison Dada";"Nanxun Blossom Hill";"No.109
column7: 120.4313189";;Hotel;;;2017;"Qiushuli Blossom Hill is located in Nanxun
column8: Huzhou also known as the “Hidden Book Town”. During earlier times in the Republic of China
column9: another renowned building entitled ‘Hidden Book’ was built by the wealthiest person in Nanxun Town Liu Chenggan’s Jiayetang. In 1930
column10: he built another villa and named it “Qiu Shu Li”. Dariel Studio carefully renovated this ancient building
column11: taking intricate measures to ensure the preservation of its heritage. Inspired by the owner Liu Chenggan’s collecting book of achievements
column12: Dariel Studio chose the design concept “Hidden” and used that sense of bewilderment to reveal the story of Nanxun and Qiushuli village. Hidden can be portrayed as Liu Chenggan’s achievements in collecting books
column13: but also the subtle beauty of hiding in the gardens in South China Style
column14: and modern desires of hiding in nature and getting rid of the pressure and worries of daily life.";;;;;;;"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/Nanxun%20Blossom%20Hill_1_0.jpg

column1: Hotel Dariel Studio Xi'An Blossom Hill;"Dariel Studio & Maison Dada";"Xi'An Blossom Hill";"No.90
column6: 108.969777";;Hotel;;;2020;"Xi’an Blossom Hill Boutique Hotel is located in Chang'an City
column7: who boasts the reputation of ""the ancient capital of thirteen Dynasties"". The hotel is adjacent to the Lotus palace of the Tang Dynas-ty. As a royal garden that once showed the style of the glorious period of the Tang Dynasty
column8: it is also a place where the royal nobles
column9: literati and civilians gathered together to travel. Its cross-cultural richness
column10: even after such a long time
column11: still vibrates. With such unique and strong regional characteristics
column12: Dariel Studio merges new trends and ancient charms and achieves to design a bridge through time
column13: offering guests a pleasant journey back to the Tang Dynasty.";;;;;;;"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/Xi%27an%20Blossom%20Hill_1_0.jpg

column1: Hotel Dariel Studio Ningbo Blossom Hill;"Dariel Studio & Maison Dada";"Ningbo Blossom Hill";"No.1518
column7: 121.672356";;Hotel;;;2019;"Ningbo Blossom Hill Boutique Hotel is located in Hanling village on the south bank of Dongqian Lake. Since ancient times
column8: Hanling has been a transportation hub with flocked merchants and prosperous marketplace. In 1140
column9: Shi Hao
column10: the Prime Minister of the Southern Song Dynasty
column11: passed by and wrote a poem: ""The landscape of Siming Mountain is different from the rest of the world
column12: and the scenery of the Dongqian Lake is particularly beautiful
column13: inside which there is a village called Hanling filled with sounds of the fishing songs
column14: woodcutting and axes"". The bustling atmos-phere of that period is evident. Ningbo Blossom Hill Hotel grew out of a wood-structured shop building with a history of one hundred years.";;;;;;;http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/Ningbo%20Blossom%20Hill_1.jpg

column1: Fermob, Parlement Européen;;"Parlement Européen";"L’esplanade Solidarnosc 1980
column3: 4.3739775";;Office;;;2019;"The Esplanade Solidarność 1980 – with the Agora Simone Veil at its centre – defines the European Parliament site in Brussels
column4: connecting its buildings with the Place du Luxembourg
column5: the Brussels-Luxembourg train station and Parc Léopold. It’s the ideal place to grab a sandwich
column7: or even just soak up the atmosphere of the European Parliament enjoying Fermob furniture. The Agora Simone Veil is at the centre of the Esplanade Solidarność 1980 and offers an impressive architectural backdrop. It is a great place from which to admire the architecture of the European Parliament’s Altiero Spinelli
column8: Willy Brandt and Joszef Antall buildings. All three are named after charismatic figures who played an important role in the construction of the European Union.";;;;;https://www.europarl.europa.eu/visiting/en/visitor-offer/brussels/esplanade;;"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/05.jpg

column1: Fermob, Stavros Niarchos Foundation Cultural Center;;"Stavros Niarchos Foundation Cultural Center";"Leof. Vasilissis Sofias 86Α
column4: 23.7557178";;"Cultural space";;;2015;"When architect Renzo Piano first visited the area where the SNFCC was to be built
column5: he immediately realized that the link between the urban and the natural landscapes had been cut; that the coastal avenue had separated the neighborhood from the sea. Renzo Piano was inspired by the name of the local area (Kallithea
column6: which literally means ""beautiful view’’) and decided to give back to the local people the beautiful view towards the sea. This idea was implemented conceptually in the most simple and effective way by lifting one side of a piece of paper and showing the gradual rise of the land towards the sea.";;;;;https://www.snfcc.org/en;;"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/BISTRO_Fondation%20Stravros%20Niarchos_Ath%C3%A8nes_Gr%C3%A8ce.JPG

column1: Baccarat Hotel;Jouffre;"Baccarat Hotel";"28 West 53Rd Street New York
column3: -73.9773752";;Hotel;;;2015;"A unique association reunited French designers Gilles & Boissier and Jouffre on the prestigious first Baccarat Hotel in New York
column4: to achieve the wall upholstery in the lobby lounge of the hotel. Everything started with an original idea: creating the effect of hundreds of pleats unveiling one after another all around the four walls of the lobby lounge of the brand new Baccarat Hotel in Manhattan
column5: due to open soon right in front of the MoMA. The ateliers Jouffre took up the challenge offered by the designers Gilles & Boissier and went beyond the traditional techniques of wall covering. For months
column8: improved and perfected a new approach of wall upholstery.";;;;;;"Eric Laignel";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/Jouffre_Gilles%20%26%20Boissier_Baccarat_%C2%A9%20Eric%20Laignel_05.jpg

column3: -73.9791558";;"Private residence";;;2015;"Jouffre was given the opportunity to participate in their first project within the One57 tower
column4: designed by French Architect Christian de Portzamparc. Positioned on the 63rd floor
column5: New York-based designers Drake/Anderson conceived an apartment
column6: trusting Jouffre to use all three of it’s savoir-faires in order to help realize their vision. The draperies department fabricated all the window treatments for the bedrooms in fabrics from Fadini Borghi
column7: Sabina Fay Braxton and Lauren Hwang woven by Holland & Sherry. Jouffre’s installers also set up the wall-upholstery on the walls of the master bedroom. For the guest bedroom
column8: the upholstery department constructed a beautiful bed in a Charles Schambourg woven leather.";;;;;;"Marco Ricca Studio";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/Jouffre_DrakeAnderson_One57_%C2%A9%20Marco%20Ricca%20Studio_06.jpg

The Skygarden : Show Case Apartment;"Elliott Barnes Interiors";"The Skygarden : Show Case Apartment";"Tokyo
column4: 2019";"Private residence";;;2017;"The complete interior design and decoration of a 275m² apartment near the Roppongi district in Tokyo. Located on the upper level of a residential building in a park
column5: the theme of the ""skygarden"" arrived instantaneously to guide the choice of materials and finishes. The creation of a double height entry connects the entertaining areas with the sleeping quarters that are placed on an upper level. A large amber glass covered structure receives leaves that appear to fall from the sky. The glass piece hides the main stair. A pleated leather wall
column7: provides an intricate textured backdrop. The combined living dining area gives onto a planted terrace. The materials and finishes in this area work in concert with the exterior foliage. The main bedroom also plays on the theme of an articulated wall surface that also serves as a headboard. Niches are created to reduce scale at the bed and support built in furniture elements.";;;;;;"Kenta Hasegawa";"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/recup_image_1586871861_0.jpg
column9: http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/recup_image_1586871863.jpg"

column1: Hotel Ritz Carlton Wolfsburg;"Elliott Barnes Interiors";"Hotel Ritz Carlton Wolfsburg";"Parkstraße 1
Kit's Dream;"Elliott Barnes Interiors";"Kit's Dream";"Marrakech
column4: it was important to arrive in a refreshing atmosphere that provided a respite from the Moroccan heat. She thus treated the floor of the entrance in blue “zelliges”
column6: in order to recall the sea between New York and Marrakech. Her living room was separated from the entrance by curtains in ""Atlantic blue"" fabric with green tiebacks. A double-door on the left repeated the motif of palm tree leaves and gave access to the bathroom with a double basin vanity in ""Calacatta Luxuoso"". To the left of the vanity she created a large bathtub recessed in a niche
column7: and dominated by an arabesque inspired by Berber symbols. The room was the heart of her space. She imagined the lower part of the walls in a dried earth color. The upper part of the walls
column8: would be treated in an arabesque “bas-relief”. The motif would originate from a frieze at a certain height on the wall. Gradually
column9: the arabesque would fade to create a large drawing of peaks and valleys. She said she would center the room with a high four-poster bed. In addition to protecting her while she slept
column10: this ""master-piece"" would be illuminated to provide a soft intimate light in the room. Here the zelliges of the floor recalled the traces left by her steps in the sands of the Sahara.";;;;;;;"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/recup_image_1586871865.jpg

column1: Walking on Clouds;"Elliott Barnes Interiors";"Walking on Clouds";"Bangkok
column3: 100.5017651";;"Private residence";;;2019;"A private 800m² apartment on the 67th and 68th floors of the MahaNakon Tower in Bangkok. “Walking on the clouds"" is the theme of this project. A very fluid and open layout with very few closed rooms (two bedrooms
column4: a massage room and three bathrooms) all sparsely furnished allow uninterrupted views of Bangkok. Full height windows give the impression that the sky and the clouds traverse the interior spaces. Several sliding partitions and Chinese works from the 17th century complete this refined
column5: light and elegant atmosphere. The two key moments in the apartment experience are a reception area with a sort of ""bow window"" cantilevered from the facade (see the view from the outside) and an eight meter high double volume from which one may enjoy the sunsets. Throughout the entire project the floor is covered with a blue-gray Chinese limestone. The floor mixes with the sky and clouds to give the impression of floating";;;;;;;http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/recup_image_1586871867.jpg

column1: A Spirit of Place;"Elliott Barnes Interiors";"A Spirit of Place";"Tokyo
column3: 139.6503106";;"Private residence";;;2020;"The complete interior design and decoration of a 125m² apartment in the Toranomon district of Tokyo. A Spirit of Place is the concept that guides the forms and finishes which are used to a create an expression that references the location of the Toranomon Project while at the same time giving a new voice to certain traditional Japanese crafts. These two orientations blend together to create a kaleidoscope of dreamlike urban and cultural impressions. As a result different almost surrealistic narratives come together to make a living environment that is amusing and unique.";;;;;;;"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/recup_image_1586871868.jpg

column4: harvesting and processing are performed in the same geographical area
column5: using a recognized traditional “savoir faire”. column4: 2019";"Cultural space";;;2017;"The salon ( both from afar and detail shot ) was the challenging room as it was the first room to enter after the entrance hall. It was meant to display their most expensive bags as adjacent was the exotic skin fashion collec- tion. Singapore is known for its vegetation but we were not allowed to bring in tall trees so Asian topiaries were used. Gildas Berthelot sculptural bronze bench and side table as the organic touch vegetation

column6: Hubert le Gall petrified wood gueridon intermingle with Martino Gamper armchair and Gio Ponti stools. Introduction of furniture through a tropical cul- ture with Brazil through Martin Eisler chairs and Joaquim Tenreiro sofa and a handknotted wild silk carpet by Fort Street Studio produced in Nepal. You do not see the artwork in these photos but they were loaned from a collector that resonated instantaneously with the guests.";;;;;http://www.tatumcompany.com/tatum-events/2017/10/13/an-exclusive-event-by-louis-vuitton-at-atbara-house;;"http://map.lefrenchdesign.org/sites/default/files/photos/recup_image_1586871697.jpg
